quiz.title: Unit 7: Imperfect Competition (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Applied Game Theory & Cartel Dynamics
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Payoff Matrices, Nash Equilibrium, Cartel Instability, Antitrust Policy, Real-World Oligopoly

questions.question: In a payoff matrix for two firms deciding whether to set a high or low price, the Nash equilibrium occurs when both set low prices. This outcome is an example of:
questions.explanation: If both firms have a dominant strategy to 'low price,' the Nash equilibrium will be (Low, Low), even if (High, High) would yield higher joint profits—this is the prisoner's dilemma.

questions.question: If a cartel agreement breaks down, it is usually because:
options: Members have an incentive to cheat to increase individual profit.
Demand for the product becomes more elastic.
Members want to increase market transparency.
questions.explanation: Each member can increase its own profit by secretly lowering price or increasing output beyond its quota, undermining the cartel—a classic cheating incentive.

questions.question: A firm in an oligopoly that follows the pricing behavior of a dominant firm in the industry is engaging in:
questions.explanation: Price leadership is a form of tacit collusion where one firm (the leader) sets prices and others (followers) match, avoiding explicit agreements.

questions.question:
Refer to the payoff matrix below. The dominant strategy for Firm B is:

Firm B
      High Price   Low Price
Firm A High  (10, 10)   (2, 12)
       Low   (12, 2)    (5, 5)
questions.explanation: For Firm B: If A chooses High, B gets 10 with High vs. 12 with Low → choose Low. If A chooses Low, B gets 2 with High vs. 5 with Low → choose Low. Low price is dominant.

questions.question: In the same matrix, the Nash equilibrium is:
questions.explanation: Both firms have a dominant strategy of Low price. Thus (Low, Low) is the Nash equilibrium—neither firm can improve by unilaterally changing.

questions.question: Antitrust laws are designed to:
options: Allow price fixing if it benefits consumers.
questions.explanation: Antitrust laws (like the Sherman Act) aim to prevent anti-competitive behavior: monopolization, collusion, mergers that reduce competition.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common feature of monopolistic competition but NOT of oligopoly?
questions.explanation: Monopolistic competition has many small firms; oligopoly has few large interdependent firms. Interdependence and kinked demand are oligopoly traits.

questions.question: If oligopolistic firms engage in limit pricing, they are attempting to:
questions.explanation: Limit pricing means setting price low enough to make entry unattractive for potential rivals, preserving market power in the long run.

questions.question: In the long-run equilibrium of monopolistic competition, price equals:
questions.explanation: Due to free entry/exit, firms earn zero economic profit in the long run, so P = ATC (but P > MC and ATC is not minimized).

questions.question: Which market structure is most likely to use non-price competition such as advertising and product differentiation?
questions.explanation: Monopolistically competitive firms rely heavily on advertising and product variation to differentiate their goods, since they cannot compete solely on price.
